help:
Wellcome to Python Calculator.
Navigate through this help using the buttons above, or by clicking the desired subject to the left.
This calculator is ready to start using. Just type any calculation you desire (like 5+8*4.5-2) and hit Enter to get the result.
You can use your keyboard, numpad, or just by clicking the buttons. The are a few advanced options in this calculator, but you don't need to know them to start calculating simple things.
Good luck!
In this section we will describe some ONLY BASIC functionalities of this calculator.
Through the menu (located at the top) you can access all functions of the calculator. Simple & advanced. You will notice that there are some menu options that have a kewboard shortcut (Like Ctrl+X to switch to hexadecimal mode). Some doesn't (Like the 'About...' screen) because I didn't think it's useful.
Feel free to browse the menu and try some by yourself.
In this field you will enter your calculations. You can use your keyboard, or the mouse (by clicking the keypads on the screen).
This field is smart. It won't let you enter illegal digits (we will discuss it later), and it cannot be blank (only Zero). But it's not too smart, if you enter some funny operation like 3+*2, you will not be able to get a result. When it's angry at you, it blinks red for about a second :)
For general info - we are using mainly the python interpreter (with some inhancements).
At the left bottom, you can see the numpad. This represents the available digits in this mode. By default, you will be working in decimal mode (base 10), which simply means the numbers you are used to (if you are a normal human being and not some geek programmer). You can use all digits (from 0 to 9) and the Dot (.) The Equal sign is also there, even though it is an operator and not a digit, just because of the convension.
This pad is dynamic, by the base you are working in. Details are in the advanced section of this help.
As for this version, the operator keypad is static. It doesn't ever change. There will be all the basic operators available to you. Addition (+), Substraction (-), Multiply (*) and Division (/). You can use also the Braces '(' or ')' if you need them. Just be careful to put an operator before! For example: 5(9+6) is illegal, maybe you mean 5*(9+6)? which is legal.
